context: The regeneration under air flow at 350°C for 5h did not allow to remove all the chlorine contained in the used catalyst. Although residual chlorine was still present after the regeneration, the initial activity was almost totally recovered. TG/DT analysis showed that residual chlorine was strongly linked to the solid and that it cannot be eliminated at temperatures lower than 650°C. On the contrary to toluene oxidation, TG/DTA results also demonstrated that no coke deposit was formed during the oxidation of chlorobenzene. Thermal oxidation of chlorinated hydrocarbons in an incinerator is a common waste-disposal method. Under ideal conditions, chlorinated hydrocarbons oxidize to H2O, CO2 and HCl. The HCl can be removed easily with exhaust gas processing.
